intro: Matelea leptogenia, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its large, white, fragrant flowers that open at night, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant belongs to the Apocynaceae family, which includes milkweeds and other toxic plants. Its leaves are opposite and ovate, with a velvety texture, and its stems are often branched and covered in fine hairs. Matelea leptogenia thrives in arid or semi-arid environments, typically in rocky soils and open woodlands.
